ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: French language practice and better understanding of business trends around the francophone world
I learned about how to talk about the economy in French. I was able to not only improve my French, but learn about how businesses function and the economy function in France.
This is a great course for students wanting to learn about the business world of francophone countries. The format is similar to that of medical french, and is very clear and has a great progression

Since I am not personally studying economics or business, I got a great foundational understanding of economic concepts as well as many ethical debates such as workplace harassment and gender and racial diversity.
How to read and write French more fluently, how to have an elevated level of conversation in French.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Range of material was great, loved the class discussions, assignments graded very quickly
Really interesting discussions, although some of the questions asked by the Professor were too specific to stimulate a good conversation.

I don't have any weaknesses for this course. Students are kept engaged through the small seminar format and there is plenty of opportunity for discussion and engagement. The assignments are all clear and reasonable. I highly recommend this course! All of the assignments are finished before reading period so you don't have to worry about extra work during finals.

Strengths: the content is highly diverse and very interesting. The topics covered broad areas related to business, but all with a clear ethical lens that made the class less focused on technical knowledge and more on social dilemmas and ethical understandings. I enjoyed the variety of homework assignments from documentaries to articles to books and this provided multiple mediums for the class to learn. The professor is wonderful and consistently engages the students with his personal knowledge on all the subjects - but without being overbearing. The breakdown of the assignments is also a strength as it's evenly divided and provides opportunity to grow and improve on both oral and written french.
Weaknesses: it was hard to get feedback on ways to improve on the assignments beyond specific comments. Besides going to a language tutor, it's difficult to overcome problems in pronunciation or grammar which counts as part of the grade but is not addressed or workshopped in class.

The strength of the course is that everyone is able to freely discuss their ideas in a judgment-free zone. The only weaknesses that I can think of are due to the virtual format but nothing to do with the actual course itself.
Love the materials and the style of the course! There's very little that I would want to change about it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Instructor made good use of the platform and engaged students directly to avoid "zoom fatigue"
All of them were great. The students are all kept engaged in the course through the small format and active discussions.
Professor Tertrain would occasionally put us into break out rooms and let us discuss some questions that he had prepared which increase level of engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Great French class for non majors looking to keep up practice
Yes, especially for someone who wants to take a French class that is different from normal culture and literature classes.
100%! Definitely take this course as well as medical french! Leo Tertrain is an amazing professor.

Yes absolutely! The content is interesting and is super accessible for all levels of understanding about French business culture. The professor is quite receptive and engaged with the content as well.
I would absolutely recommend this class to another student especially if they're interested in business and would like to improve on their french.

I would most definitely recommend this course and medical French; they are both super fun and useful courses and a great way to continue to improve your French skills, especially your speaking skills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a seminar over zoom where we discussed the course materials and submitted our reading responses in the chat and responded to other classmates' thoughts.
